boardgame.name: Masters of the Tourist Trophy
boardgame.description:
Masters of the Tourist Trophy is a motorcycle racing sports replay game simulating the Isle of Man Tourist Trophy. The Isle of Man TT has, for many years, been regarded as the most prestigious and oldest motorcycle race in the world... and also the most dangerous motorcycle road-race in the world!

Summary

The game is typical of Lambourne's sports replay simulations in that it takes place on tables and charts (no board or counters) with minimal player decisions required.

The simulation has been developed to capture the confused progress of the Isle of Man mountain bike races. With drivers setting off at different times, the system is able to record both the positions on the course from a spectator viewpoint as well as keep track of the actual driver times for determining a race winner. As in the actual Tourist Trophy, crashes and mishaps are common and not all riders can be expected to finish.

The game includes race control sheets for six different classes of race, from the ultra-lightweight 125cc bikes to the Formula One 1200cc monsters. The famous TT sidecars are also represented in a class of their own.

The drivers represented and rated are drawn from the "all-time greats" from over 100 years of Tourist Trophy events.

Brief outline of the Game System

The race is set up on a Race Control Sheet that lists Driver Name, Driver Rating and Start Time. For each stage of the race every driver rolls two pairs of dice (red and green) to advance their progress.

The difference between the green "+" and red "-" dice, when added to the driver performance rating, determine whether the driver performance improves or degrades on each stage of the lap. Comparison of the driver performance ratings will reveal the order of the drivers on the circuit as they pass each checkpoint on the circuit.

Rolling doubles on either pair of dice may improve or degrade the driver performance rating, but rolling double "6" requires a further roll on Rider Mistakes or Mechanical Trouble charts. Such problems usually result in a performance loss, but can also cause retirement through a crash or serious mechanical failure. Game charts will determine the precise location of each such accident on the circuit.

Drivers must also elect to Pit Stop at least once during the race. This can be dome at a time decided by the player and requires a die roll and chart reference to determine the effect the pit stop has on race time.

At the end of the lap the cumulative performance for each of the four lap stages can be cross-referenced against the game charts to determine the lap time and average speed for each driver on the circuit.

boardgame.name: The Tar Pits
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The road from the mine has always been a treacherous one. The scholars say that the sticky black tar that bubbles from the ground is linked to the black firestone that the miners delve for, but that's never concerned Old Gret. His mind is set on watching his footing as he crosses another rickety bridge. He doesn't want to end up like those behemoths beneath him, their bleached bones still stuck in the tar. He's so preoccupied, he doesn't notice some of the bones begin to move...

Need a quick map for an encounter?

A printable battlemap compatible with any RPG/Dungeon-Crawl game. Use as a standalone gameboard, or combine with any same-scale tileset.

Contents: A 30 x 30 map depicting a rough road, interrupted by a set of large bubbling tar pits. Rickety wooden bridges cross the tar pits, with evidence of earlier bridges that collapsed into the sticky bitumen. The bleached bones of large animals are stuck in the tar - stark reminders of the dangers of crossing the Tar Pits. Near one of the bridges is a wrecked wagon - the contents of mined ore and stone spilling out, and spattered with worringly-fresh blood.

boardgame.name: Shadow
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In Blackest Night!

Mythic Monsters: Shadow brings you a dozen and one shadowy sneaks from the realms of endless nocturn. Whether lurking in the dark and hidden places beneath the ground or emerging from beshadowed realms far beyond this mortal coil, there is something terribly cool about creatures of raw and endless darkness. From the sleek and sinister unseelie realms to the coiling, roiling, pits of eternal night, creatures of shadow have always captured our imagination, whether they are simply misunderstood dwellers in darkness or truly villains of the deepest dye. From CR 3 to 25, we bring you the living and the dead that live beyond the light, from simple shadows seeking to blot out the light and drink your life to towering nightwalkers, the devastating heralds of annihilation. The secretive and stealthy dark creepers and dark stalkers lurk within these pages, alongside the misshapen umbral shepherds and the terrifying tenebrous worms that mature into beautiful but deadly gloomwings. A quartet of killer kytons are found, from the bloodthirsty lampadarius and the vivisecting interlocutor to the sinister sacristan and the horrid eremite lords of the kyton race. Finally, the umbral dragon graces these pages with its sleek shimmer-gloom, breathing darkness and devouring light. As if a dozen existing monsters were not enough, the mysterious shadowpeople exist forever on the edge of sight, their motives as much an enigma as their true face and form. For heroes or villains wishing to tame the shadow, we also present a mythic version of the shadowdancer prestige class, with mythic versions of each and every class feature!

boardgame.name: Trio of Taverns (Pathfinder Edition)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Trio of Taverns, the third installment in the Tangible Taverns line, features not one, but, you guessed it, three taverns. Give your players the chance to explore what happens when a capable barbarian known for beheading his opponents falls in love with jam making and settles down to open his own shop, or let your players try to seduce a city noble by taking her to the classiest and most romantic tavern in town, or just stick with the basics and let them dance the night away with great entertainment and delicious food, while avoiding the shadier elements.

This instalment of Tangible Taverns brings you three smaller scale taverns each with rumour and event tables, a tavern map, and a description of frequent faces about the establishment (which include names, physical features and personalities for some tavern employees and patrons).

With all that, more original artwork than ever before, and "More Faces at the Tavern", featuring NPCs ready to be slotted into the tavern your PCs are visiting, you are all set to have some role-playing fun when your PCs stop off for a drink.

Like the troublesome mischievous creature we are named after, dire rugrat publishing delights in bringing a little excitement to what could have otherwise been a peaceful, though perhaps comparably dull evening at the local tavern. Our line of books, Tangible Taverns, is designed to bring life back to the much visited watering hole, a common setting while adventurers are on the road.

boardgame.name: The Dying Flame
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

For the 5th edition of the world's most popular roleplaying game!

This is an adventure setting for level 15-17 characters. It's a dungeon crawl into a mummy lord's tomb. What? A dungeon crawl for tier 3 characters? Yes!

Take a break from saving the world, blow the dust (or sand) off of your fifty feet of hemp rope, and check the tar on the end of your torches because evil is stiring under the sands.

This adventure location doesn't inclue a narative story, it's just a dungeon, but there are random events, traps, and a few hooks to stiminulate your imagination.

The module also includes stats for a host of advanced mummies to challenge high level characters (don't worry, they've been extensivley playtested for fairness and deadliness). What good is a dungeon delve without a reward? There're several cool magic items fit for your legendary heroes.

But best of all there's so many ways to die!

Burried in sand, crushed by golden ceilings, fed alive to swarms of demonic scarabs, or simply cursed to walk the halls of the mummy lord's tomb forever, searching for a way to finally extinguish the Dying Flame.

boardgame.name: Zero Escape 3: Time Dilemma
ZERO ESCAPE 刻のジレンマ
ZERO ESCAPE 刻のジレンマ
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma
Zero Time Dilemma
boardgame.description:
December 31, 2028. Nevada desert. Nine people have been living and performing experiments for the past five days in the Dcom facility. On the sixth day, they discover they are trapped in confinement rooms, an unfamiliar black bracelet strapped to their left wrists. A mysterious figure in a mask appears before them, demanding that they play the "Decision Game." "The lives of you, me, and the human race hang in the balance." Transported to a shelter underground, they are divided into 3 teams and left in separate wards. Which team will manage to stay alive...? The fate of all mankind rests on their decision!

Zero Time Dilemma is the third entry in the acclaimed Zero Escape series. The mysterious "Zero" traps 9 participants within an underground shelter, dividing them equally between 3 wards that are connected to an elevator shaft in the middle. The only way out – passing through a locked X-Door to access the elevator. Six passwords are required to unlock the door, and each password is revealed only after a participant dies. Zero's "Decision Game" will offer teams the opportunity to kill other participants through a variety of means to obtain the necessary passwords so they may escape.

Source: The Game Website.
